achievements: During the reporting period, responsibility with the Office of the Prime Minister (2008 - 2011), and subsequently with the Ministry for Tourism, Culture & the Environment (in 2012), assisted by the Malta Environment and Planning Authority. In 2013, however, some of the responsibilities of the Malta Environment and Planning Authority with regards to the implementation of this Directive shifted to the newly set-up Wild Birds Regulation Unit within the Ministry for Sustainable Development, the Environment and Climate Change Maintaining Biodiversity During the reporting period the responsible Ministry, together with the Malta Environment and Planning Authority, developed the National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (NBSAP) for Malta, which was launched in December 2012. This national strategy defines a comprehensive framework for safeguarding Malta’s biodiversity over the period 2012 to 2020, as set by the National Environmental Policy. For further information refer to: https://www.mepa.org.mt/biodiversity-nbsap and http://www.mepa.org.mt/file.aspx?f=9219. Moreover, the national Malta Ornis Committee, established by virtue of Regulation 10 of the Conservation of Wild Birds Regulations (S.L. 504.71) provides a formal platform for stakeholder discussions on the policies related to the conservation of wild birds. Designation of Special Protection Areas Since its accession to the European Union and up to 2012, Malta has designated a total of thirteen Special Protection Areas (SPAs). In 2008 Malta designated two new SPAs under the Birds Directive which included the area from Wied Moqbol to Il-Ponta ta’ Bengħisa and the coastal cliffs of Ta’ Ċenċ in Gozo. The sites were published through Government Notices 812 and 859 of 2008 respectively, under both the Environment and Development Planning Act (CAP. 504). Moreover, as part of Malta’s Seabird Project additional marine sites are also currently being identified for such designation. Additionally, in 2013 Malta identified its first Marine Important Bird Area (IBA) around the Malta-Gozo channel. Moreover, during the reporting interim, management plans are being developed for all terrestrial SPAs and SACs forming part of the Natura 2000 network and these are to be finalised by the end of 2014. The process of preparing management plans and other management instruments includes the gathering of information, carrying out of surveys and updating existing data, defining the conservation objectives and identifying management measures for each site, with intensive stakeholder involvement and participation. The project of developing management plans and management frameworks for all terrestrial Natura 2000 sites including SPAs is also aimed to increase awareness amongst the general public and stakeholders. The project is co-financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) under Measure 323 of the Rural Development Program for Malta. The boundaries for the sites can be found at http://www.mepa.org.mt (under links to Environment - Official Manual - Government Notices) and http://www.mepa.org.mt/impnatareas-pas-int-n2k-dsmap. Environment Assessments The environmental impact of selected activities and projects on birds was assessed when relevant and moreover, environment assessments or other appropriate ecological assessments were also required for various activities, as specified by the Environment Impact Assessment Regulations (S.L. 504.79) and the Flora, Fauna and Natural Habitats Protection Regulations (S.L. 504.73) respectively. These also include the appropriate assessments in terms of Article 6 and 7 of the Habitats Directive. In addition, in view of the Strategic Environmental Assessment Regulations (S.L. 504.102), a strategic environmental assessment was also required on any plan and program which was likely to have significant effect on the environment, such assessments took into consideration both bird species and their habitats. During the reporting period a total of 464 applications were screened to determine whether or not further assessments were required. Action Plans During the reporting period Malta implemented various activities listed in the Commission’s management plans for huntable species and a complete report of such measures was submitted to the European Commission in August 2013. Such measures include: • Public awareness: regular awareness on huntable species due to press articles, press releases as well as related activities linked with the LIFE+ Gawdihom Ħielsa project. • Habitats Protection: various existing legal provisions of the Environment and Development Planning Act are in place, declaring various important sites in the Maltese Islands as Nature Reserves, Bird Sanctuaries (BSs), Special Areas of Conservation (SACs), Special Protection Areas (SPAs), Tree Protection Areas (TPAs), Areas of Ecological Importance (AEIs) and Sites of Scientific Importance (SSIs). The Ramsar sites (which are also SACs, SPAs and BSs) are both managed on the basis of a management agreement with BirdLife Malta. The development of management plans for other Natura 2000 sites and relevant publicity is also being addressed. • Annual Bag Statistics & Bag Limits: Carnet de Chasse (CdC) - annual bag statistics) reports are compiled on an annual basis and are used for determining whether a spring hunting season could be possible (depending on the numbers of the species concerned caught in autumn). If a spring season is possible the CdC will be used for the computation of the spring bag limits. Such quotas must be inversely proportional to the autumn hunting effort and linked to the 1% mortality of the species concerned. An SMS system is in place to assist in the enforcement of bag limits during derogation periods. Enforcement has also been consistently further reinforced by additional police officials/hunting marshals. • Ringing: (see below for further information). • Annual estimates of breeding success through national research activities on breeding grounds: In 2007 Malta commissioned a study on farmland birds, which was conducted by BirdLife Malta (BLM), and produced a breeding bird atlas which was published in the Malta Breeding Bird Atlas (Raine, A.; Sultana, J. & Gillings, S. (2009); Malta Breeding Bird Atlas 2008.) • Research on Migration Patterns: Malta has commissioned independent scientific studies on the migration of Streptopelia turtur (Eng: Turtle Dove, Malt: il-gamiem) and Coturnix coturnix (Eng: Quail, Malt.: is-summien) during spring migration of 2008, 2009, 2011, 2012 and 2013. Furthermore, as from 2014 such annual studies shall be broadened to also incorporate part of the autumn season. • Investigation of the potential competition with Collared Dove: the collared dove is a relatively recent regular breeder in Malta, known from breeding stations in the north east of Malta and the central parts of Gozo, and was introduced in Comino. Their numbers are increasing annually since 2004, as indicated by studies commissioned by Malta and/or carried out by BLM, e.g. Raine et al. (2009) and Sultana et al. (2011). No precise interspecific competition assessments have been carried out between the collared and turtle doves, also because turtle doves do not breed in Malta. However, it has been noted that the collared dove is a highly adaptable breeder, preferring suburban human habitation areas with gardens and small cultivated holdings, with scattered individual or small groves, such as at Santa Marija Estate in Mellieħa, the Government Nursery and Villa Rundle, the latter two at Rabat Victoria (Gozo). • Control on the Alien Japanese Quail (C.c .japonica) and its various hybrids (C.c.coturnix x C.c. japonica): Japanese and hybrid quails are not an issue in Malta, and no specialised breeding centres occur. However, provisions on the introduction of invasive alien species have been legally set up through the Flora, Fauna and Natural Habitats Protection Regulations (S.L. 504.73). Research & Monitoring The breeding population of Calonectris diomedea (Eng: Scopoli’s Shearwater, Malt: iċ-ċiefa), Puffinus yelkouan (Eng: Yelkouan Shearwater, Malt: il-garnija) and Hydrobates pelagicus (Eng: European Storm-petrel, Malt: il-kanġu ta’ Filfla) are continuously monitored and moreover, research on their breeding biology is also being undertaken. Malta has also commissioned a number of independent monitoring surveys on Streptopelia turtur and Coturnix coturnix during the spring season with the aim of verifying the concentration of these species and the timing of their migration. These reports, moreover, assist in the overall supervision and verification regime of the hunting season concerned. Control of Alien Species Due to the increase in human activities at Rdum tal-Madonna (an area in the North of Malta) there was a rise in the predation of the Puffinus yelkouan by rats and as part of a Life+ project Malta carried out a successful rat eradication program (vide below for more details). Moreover, the control of Comino’s feral pigeon community was also permitted since these were impacting the birds in the surrounding area, particularly seabirds and causing damage to the nesting sites of the Monticola solitarius (Blue Rock Thrush, Malt.: il-merill). The culling, which was monitored by the Competent Authority, was carried out by the Animal Welfare Promotion & Services Department. Nature Permitting As a regulatory tool for the implementation of legal obligations and policies, Malta currently uses a permitting system in relation to protected areas and species. Permits are only issued if the requested endeavour is not deemed to threaten biodiversity and in case of derogations, in line with the provisions of Article 9 of the Birds Directive. Such derogations are reported to the EU Commission through Malta’s report of derogations allowed under Article 9 of the Birds Directive. EU LIFE Projects Yelkouan Shearwater project The EU LIFE Yelkouan Shearwater project, which was in operation between 2007 and 2010, aimed at enhancing the breeding population of the Puffinus yelkouan through the protection of its main breeding site, a Special Protection Area at Rdum tal-Madonna. In view that one of the major pressures on the Puffinus yelkouan is the predation by rats, one of the projects initiatives was to manage the occurrence of this species on the site. This initiative has yielded results since a detectable increase in the chick’s survival rate has been noted. In addition, electronic tagging devices have also been placed on the adults and this should help gather further information on the foraging and feeding activities of this bird. Gawdihom Ħielsa An EU funded information project entitled Gawdihom Ħielsa (Enjoy them free) ran for two years between January 2009 and June 2011 and aimed at raising awareness on the importance of Malta for bird migration and the impacts of trapping on Malta’s wildlife. The project in addition to organising an international seminar on the effects of trapping also produced various reports on bird migration and trapping, an informative calendar, bird posters, stickers for children and a TV series. Malta Seabird Project This EU funded project, which is currently ongoing (September 2011 – June 2016), aims at creating a catalogue of marine Important Bird Areas (IBAs) for three seabird species; Puffinus yelkouan, Calonectris diomedea and Hydrobates pelagicus. This project shall employ various bird tracking methodologies to gain further knowledge on key areas, which sites shall then be recommended as marine Special Protection Areas. Bird-Ringing Initiatives A local Non Governmental Organisation (BirdLife Malta) carried out a number of bird ringing activities especially during the migratory season. Such activities were carried out by ringers who were trained and licensed from a ringing scheme which was accepted by the European Union for Bird Ringing (EURING). Moreover, the related ringing data was published in BirdLife’s scientific journal –Il-Merill and reported to the European Commission through Malta’s report of derogations allowed under Article 9 of the Birds Directive. Communication & Awareness Malta has undertaken a number of information and education initiatives to promote the conservation of wild birds and their habitats. Such initiatives have varied from articles in local newspapers, information panels, dissemination of information through television programmes and the organisation of educational tours. Moreover, the website of the Malta Environment and Planning Authority (MEPA) http://www.mepa.org.mt/home?l=1 also includes sections on species, habitats, data management, nature protection, legislation, nature protection policies, protected areas, nature publications and reports, and biodiversity permitting. Posters on protected bird species, available in digital format on the MEPA website, were also distributed to interested parties. A series of bookmarks and coasters depicting important Maltese species have also been produced by the Authority. These have been widely distributed free of charge to the public, local bars and restaurants. Since Biodiversity Day in 2010, MEPA has been very active in bridging the gap between policy and nature and it has set up monthly Biodiversity Tours to Protected Areas, whereby MEPA officials provide free guided tours to selected protected areas on Sunday. After a very successful trial period in early 2010 (with just two sites), these tours proved so successful that they are now being carried out for the fourth consecutive year. In parallel, MEPA started participating in the popular Sunday show ‘Malta u lil Hinn Minnha’, an award-winning TV show during which MEPA provides a weekly guided visit to a protected area, with information on snippets on Maltese heritage. In addition a number of national seminars addressed to relevant stakeholders and also to the public in general have been held in relation to the Birds Directive and related policy. A working group, consisting of key stakeholders including MEPA, the police, the Wild Birds Regulation Unit, representatives of the hunting community as well as representatives of Birdlife (Malta) is being set up in order to draw up a national strategy for the eradication of illegal killing, trapping and trade of wild birds. This national strategy is envisaged to have a strong communication component.

achievements: Lovgivningen for den danske implementering af naturdirektiverne herunder fuglebeskyttelsesdirektivet er blevet væsentligt revideret og konsolideret i rapporteringsperioden. Det inkluderer lovgivning hos sektorministerier, der omhandler fiskeri, energi og transport, og følger en tilgang med sektorintegration, hvor det enkelte sektor ministerium er ansvarlige for, at der sker en vurdering af eventuelle konsekvenser af planer og projekter indenfor deres respektive ressort. Danmark har nu en vidtrækkende lovgivning, der skal sikre, at alle relevante planer og projekter behandles med respekt for habitatdirektivets artikel 6.3 (dvs. en vurdering af eventuelle konsekvenser af planer og projekter), denne artikel gælder også for fuglebeskyttelsesdirektivets og relevante arter. Det er det generelle indtryk, at sektormyndighederne tager disse lovmæssige tiltag alvorligt. Hvis det ikke skulle være tilfældet, vil de relevante ankenævn kunne gribe ind, i tilfælde af at der foretages utilstrækkelige vurderinger, der ikke respekterer direktivet. Systemet har vist sig at være effektivt, i de tilfælde hvor EU kommissionen har startet en sag eller fremsendt en åbningsskrivelse (bortset fra et tilfælde, der endnu ikke er tilendebragt), er sagerne blevet lukket igen af kommisionen. I mange tilfælde kan afværgeforanstaltninger eller rettidige ændringer i planer eller projekter sikre undgåelse af skade på fuglebeskyttelsesområderne og de listede arter. Nogle myndigheder har indhentet ny viden til administrationen af direktivet fx har Energistyrelsen og DONG fået gennemført studier af fuglenes bevægelsesmønstre og displacement i forbindelse med planlagningen af havvindmølleparker, og Naturstyrelsen får gennemført studier af effekterne af opsætning af kæmpevindmøller på land i relation til at afdække kollisionsrisici og ændrede bevægelsesmønstre. Alle danske fuglebeskyttelsesområder er dækket af en systematisk Natura 2000 planlægningstilgang. Natura 2000-områderne dækker ca. 8,3 % af det danske landareal og 17,7 % af det marine areal. Denne planlægningsproces betyder, at der er udarbejdet en naturplan for i alt 246 Natura 2000-områder. Siden er udpeget 6 nye marine områder. Disse vil blive indrullet i planlægningen fra næste planperiode fra 2016-2021. Tilhørende handleplaner på et mere detaljeret niveau er udarbejdet af kommuner (for private arealer) og statslige lodsejere for alle 246 områder. Planerne ligger på Naturstyrelsens hjemmeside: www.naturstyrelsen.dk/Naturbeskyttelse/Natura2000/Natura_2000_planer/ Planerne blev offentliggjort i december 2011. Til grund for planerne ligger en såkaldt basisanalyse, der er en opsummering af den eksisterende viden for det enkelte område. Baseret på erfaringerne fra første planperiode er den danske miljømålslov blevet revideret. For at vurdere fremdrift i planlægningstiltagene er under udarbejdelse såkaldte Natura 2000-tilstandssystemer for levestederne for 16 forskellige fuglearter. Denne tilgang forventes udbredt til flere andre fuglearter. Tilstandssystemet er et dialogværktøj bl.a. overfor lodsejere, der er møntet på tilstanden af konkrete arealer. Natura 2000-planer er bindende for de relevante myndigheder. Tiltagene for at forbedre Natura 2000 naturen vil indenfor planperioden udmønte sig i en række forbedrende aktiviteter inklusiv naturforvaltning (græsning, høslæt, rydning mv.), regulering af forstyrrelser, genetablering af naturlige vandløb og søer, konvertering af arealer til Natura 2000 natur samt regulering af fiskeri. Derudover vil en forbedret vandkvalitet vil blive sikret med implementering af vandplanerne og udarbejdet som en del af gennemførslen af vandrammedirektivet. Udgangspunktet for aktiviteterne er, at de bliver indgået med lodsejere på frivillig basis. De fuglearter, der indgår som udpegningsarter for Natura 2000-områderne, indgår i det danske overvågningsprogram NOVANA og overvåges som minimum en gang hvert sjette år og i visse tilfælde oftere. Direktivforpligtelserne har skabt behov for en væsentlig forøgelse af naturovervågningsindsatsen. Jagtlovens formål er at sikre arts- og individrige vildtbestande og skabe grundlag for en bæredygtig jagt. Der er fastsat jagttid på 33 fuglearter. Jagttiderne revideres som udgangspunkt hvert tredje år baseret på informationer og vurderinger om arternes bestandsudvikling samt antallet af nedlagte fugle. Der udarbejdes en faglig rapport som grundlag for revisionen. Der drives i udgangspunktet ikke jagt på fugle i yngletiden og fugle på vej til ynglepladserne om foråret, og jagttiderne varierer fra art til art som udgangspunkt indenfor tidsrummet 1. september til 31. januar. Der er desuden oprettet ca. 100 vildtreservater i Danmark, der bl.a. skal bidrage til at friholde fugleområder for jagt og/eller menneskelig færdsel. Reservaterne har forskellig størrelse, karakter og formål. Tidligere undersøgelser har vist, at vildtreservater er af stor betydning for fældende eller rastende vandfugle.
achievements_trans: The legal framework for the Danish implementation of the nature directives has been substantially amended and consolidated during the reporting period, including legislation within sectoral ministries on fishery, energy and transport, following a sector integration approach making the sectoral ministries responsible for e.g. assessments of impact of plans and projects which they are responsible for. Denmark now has an exhaustive legal framework ensuring that all relevant plans and projects are treated under the provisions of article 6.3 in the Habitate Directive which is also valid for the Bird Directive. It is the impression that authorities are now in general fully aware of these provisions, and if not the responsible complaint boards will catch up, e.g. in cases of inappropriate assessments or decisions tending to be taken without respect of the conditions given by Natura 2000 or species protection. The system has proven its stability in the few cases where the Commission has initiated a pilot procedure or an infraction case as the cases (with one pending exception) have been closed by the Commission. In many cases it is shown that mitigation measures or "smart" and timely adjustments of the plan or project can exclude negative impact on sites or species. Authorities and firms have initiated applied research projects to monitor the impact on bird movements and displacement in relation to establishment of windmill parks including the Energy Agency and the energy concern DONG for offshore windmill parks and the Ministry of Environment for large wind mills on land. A systematic planning approach has been implemented in Denmark in the Danish Natura 2000 areas. These areas cover 8.3 % of the Danish land area and 17.7 % of the marine. This planning approach implies that a management framework plan has been developed for a total of 246 Natura 2000 sites both SPAs and SACs. Since six nex marine sites have been added to the Danish list and these areas are expected to be covered by the second planning period from 2016 to 2021. More detailed action plans have been developed for private land ( municipalities) and state land (state owners) to facilitate implementation. The management plans are available at: www.naturstyrelsen.dk/Naturbeskyttelse/Natura2000/Natura_2000_planer/ The plans were launched by the Minister of Environment in December 2011. They are build upon published analysises of the existing knowledge and studies, which summarises relevant information for each Natura 2000 area. Moreover, the Danish Act on Environmental Objectives on the implementation of the Habitat and Bird Directives as well as the Water Framework Directive has been revised based on the experiences from the first proces of developing management plans. In order to assess quality of bird habitats as well as other species habitats and nature types a system at locality level has been developed as a management tool for dialouge with land owners. The Natura 2000 management plans are legally binding upon the authorities. Measures include habitat management (grazing, mowing, removal of scrub etc.), regulation of disturbing activities, , restoring watercourses and lakes regulation of fishery and coastal protection. Moreover, regulation of airborne nitrogen was undertaken through a revision of the act on domestic animals and enhanced water quality will take place through the implementation of the water plans prepared as part of the implementation of the Water Framework Directive. As the point of departure a number of measures will be agreed upon on a voluntarily basis with land owners. Regulation of hunting has been established for 33 bird species. The hunting season on a particular species varies and is being evaluated every three years. A comprehensive technical report provides the platform for such a revision. In general hunting seasons vary within the time of 1 September to 31 January. About 100 wildlife reserves have been established in Denmark and include areas with waterbirds were hunting and human traffic is regulated or forbidden. The wildlife reserves are of different size and with various aims. Earlier studies have shown that wildlife reserves are of significant importance for moulting or resting waterbirds. Birds listed in the SPAs are included in the Danish monitoring scheme NOVANA. All listed birds are monitored as a minimum once each sixth years or more often. The obligations coming from the nature directives have significantly increased the monitoring activities in Denmark.
information_on_network: Denmark has designated 113 Special Protected Areas (SPA&s) for birds included in all-together 252 Natura 2000 sites. The SPA&s comprise 14,700 km². There is a considerable geographical overlap between the habitat and bird areas and taken together the Natura 2000 sites comprise about 3,590 km² and 18,686 km² land and marine area respectively. Approximately 82 bird species listed in appendix 1 or covered by article 4.2 of the Birds Directive are listed in Denmark (Danish Agency for Nature 2010). These species have been reasons for the designation of Natura 2000 sites. Some sites are rather large, especially some coastal or marine sites such as the Eastern Bay of Aalborg or the Danish part of the Wadden Sea, which each covers more than 1,500 km². Moreover, some sites have fifty or more species and habitats listed for example Ringkøbing Fjord and the Wadden Sea and others have just one or a few such as marine sites with reefs or sandbanks or terrestrial sites containing one or a few habitats. The sites are formally designated by a statutory order. The Danish Agency for Nature in the Ministry of Environment is responsible for the designation as well as for the Natura 2000 planning process and all SPAs are included in this active planning approach. For more information see: www.naturstyrelsen.dk/Naturbeskyttelse/Natura2000/Hvad_er_Natura_2000/Danske_omraader/
monitoring_schemes: National monitoring programmes covering birds and abbreviated NOVANA have been implemented since 2004 with the aim to collect data and follow especially species listed in appendix 1 or for which SPAs have been designated. For more details: www.naturstyrelsen.dk/Naturbeskyttelse/Natura2000/Hvordan_beskytter_vi_naturen/Overvaagning
protection_of_species: The legal protection as well as the protection of certain species habitats have been implemented through the Act on Hunting and Game Management and the Nature Protection Act. The aim of the Act on Hunting and Game Management is to secure a fauna rich in species and healthy populations as a basis for sustainable hunting. For 33 bird species a hunting season has been established and these seasons is in principal revised every third year on the basis on information and assessments of the development of individual populations and the number of bagged birds. A technical report forms the basis for these revisions. The hunting seasons varies between species in principle between 1 September og 31 January. Important guidance documents has been elaborated, the main guidance document can be found here: http://www.naturstyrelsen.dk/NR/rdonlyres/A774F62A-AD26-44DC-9DCD-2A6F603CDDD4/127124/vejledningjuni2011pdf.pdf
transpose_directive: I. Designation and legal framework for the Natura 2000 planning system: Act on Environmental Objectives for Water Bodies and Internationally Protected Sites, Act on Hunting and Game Management and the Nature Protection Act.
national_bird_redlist_title: Red List index for birds in Denmark
national_bird_redlist_reference: Pihl, S. & Flensted, K. 2011. A Red List Index for breeding birds in Denmark in the period 1991-2009.

achievements: Η Κυπριακή Δημοκρατία έχει μεταφέρει την Οδηγία της ΕΕ που αφορά την προστασία και διαχείριση των Αγρίων Πτηνών (2009/147/ΕΚ), και ο σχετικός νόμος (152(Ι) 2003) εφαρμόζεται από το Υπουργείου Εσωτερικών (Υπηρεσία Θήρας & Πανίδας). Η Οδηγία και ο σχετικός νόμος προνοούν μεταξύ άλλων και στον καθορισμό των σημαντικότερων περιοχών για τη διατήρηση συγκεκριμένων ειδών ως Ζώνες Ειδικής Προστασίας (ΖΕΠ), οι οποίες περιλαμβάνονται στο δίκτυο Natura 2000. Μέχρι σήμερα έχουν καθοριστεί 30 περιοχές ως ΖΕΠ (7 το 2005, 12 το 2007, 7 το 2008, 3 το 2009 και 2 το 2013 [1 μία το 2013 η οποία αποτελεί επέκταση]), οι οποίες καλύπτουν το 16.5% περίπου της χερσαίας έκτασης της Κυπριακής Δημοκρατίας. Αυτό αποτελεί ένα σημαντικό μέρος του φυσικού αποθέματος της Δημοκρατίας. Σε ότι αφορά τις περιοχές ΖΕΠ έχει ήδη υπογραφεί Σύμβαση με εξωτερικούς Συμβούλους για την εκπόνηση Διαχειριστικών Σχεδίων για όλες τις περιοχές ΖΕΠ, συμπεριλαμβανομένου και εκτεταμένου προγράμματος διαβούλευσης. Υπολογίζεται ότι τα Διαχειριστικά Σχέδια για τις περιοχές ΖΕΠ υπολογίζεται ότι θα είναι έτοιμα μέχρι το τέλος του 2016, οπότε άμεσα θα αρχίσει η υλοποίηση συγκεκριμένων δράσεων προς επίτευξη των στόχων που θα έχουν τεθεί. Ανεξάρτητα από την εκπόνηση των Διαχειριστικών Σχεδίων, η υποχρέωση για τη διατήρηση των περιοχών ΖΕΠ και προστασίας απειλούμενων ειδών υφίσταται μέσα από εξειδικευμένες δράσεις, μέτρα και προγράμματα τα οποία υλοποιούνται από την Υπηρεσία Θήρας & Πανίδας, μαζί με άλλους εταίρους. Στη συνέχεια αναφέρονται συγκεκριμένα παραδείγματα. 1. Πρόγραμμα για τη Διατήρηση του Γύπα στην Κύπρο μέσω του Διασυνοριακού Προγράμματος Κύπρου – Ελλάδας Το έργο ΓΥΠΑΣ ξεκίνησε το Σεπτέμβριο 2011 και τελειώνει τον Ιανουάριο 2014. Επικεφαλής εταίρος του έργου είναι η Υπηρεσία Θήρας & Πανίδας (Υπ. Εσωτερικών), ενώ εταίροι στην Κύπρο είναι ο Πτηνολογικός Σύνδεσμος και το Τμήμα Δασών, και στην Κρήτη το Μουσείο Φυσικής Ιστορίας Κρήτης και ο Δήμος Γόρτυνας. Στα πλαίσια του έργου έχει κατασκευαστεί στην Κύπρο ένας κλωβός φιλοξενίας στο Λιμνάτη, έχει επεκταθεί ένας υπάρχοντας κλωβός στον Αη Γιάννη της Πάφου και κατασκευάστηκαν δύο νέες ταΐστρες για τους γύπες. Επίσης, έγιναν: παρακολούθηση των εναπομεινάντων πουλιών, διάφορες δράσεις ενημέρωσης και ευαισθητοποίησης του κοινού και παραγωγή ενημερωτικού υλικού. Στην Κρήτη δημιουργήθηκε κέντρο αποκατάστασης γυπών για την επανένταξή τους στη φύση και έγιναν παρακολούθηση του πληθυσμού και δράσεις ενημέρωσης. Τέλος, διοργανώθηκε διεθνές συνέδριο στην Κύπρο τον Μάρτιο του 2013 με τη συμμετοχή Ευρωπαίων ειδικών. Κατά τη διάρκεια του έργου εστάληκαν στην Κύπρο περίπου 30 πουλιά από την Κρήτη. 2. Αποκατάσταση και Διαχείριση της λίμνης Ορόκλινης Οι εταίροι του τριετούς έργου LIFE που ξεκίνησε τον Ιανουάριο 2012, είναι η Υπηρεσία Θήρας & Πανίδας ως επικεφαλής εταίρος, ο Πτηνολογικός Σύνδεσμος Κύπρου ως συντονιστής, το Τμήμα Περιβάλλοντος, το Τμήμα Δασών και το Κοινοτικό Συμβούλιο Βορόκληνης. Το έργο LIFE Ορόκλινη, περιλαμβάνει δράσεις διατήρησης και ενημέρωσης του κοινού που θα αντιμετωπίσουν τις διάφορες απειλές που αντιμετωπίζει η λίμνη. Οι δράσεις διατήρησης περιλαμβάνουν την περίφραξη της λίμνης ώστε να σταματήσει η όχληση που προκαλείται από την είσοδο οχημάτων διαφόρων τύπων στη λίμνη όταν πέφτει η στάθμη του νερού, την απομάκρυνση ξενικών εισβλητικών ειδών (όπως ακακίες), τη φύτευση γηγενών ειδών θάμνων και δέντρων, τη διαχείριση του νερού και αποκατάσταση της περιοχής όπου λειτουργούσε το παράνομο παζαράκι. Να σημειωθεί επίσης ότι πολλές από αυτές τις δράσεις περιλαμβάνονται και στο Διαχειριστικό Σχέδιο για τη Λίμνη Ορόκλινης. Τα οφέλη από το έργο LIFE Ορόκλινη είναι πολλαπλά, αφού το έργο θα αναβαθμίσει ένα σημαντικό υδροβιότοπο, κάτι που θα αποτελέσει ένα είδος μοντέλου για μελλοντικά έργα, θα συντελέσει στην περιβαλλοντική ευαισθητοποίηση του κοινού της περιοχής και στην ανάδειξή της ως τόπου περιβαλλοντικής ενημέρωσης των μαθητών, θα βοηθήσει στη διαχείριση και έλεγχο της στάθμης του νερού στη λίμνη και άλλα. Παράλληλα η Υπηρεσία Θήρας & Πανίδας εκπονεί συστηματικές έρευνες και παρακολούθηση πληθυσμιακών δεδομένων διάφορων ειδών πτηνοπανίδας. Είδη που καταγράφονται είναι μεταξύ άλλων αρπαχτικά, ενδημικά πτηνά, είδη με μειωμένους ή/ και απειλούμενους πληθυσμούς σε Ευρωπαϊκό επίπεδο, κορακοειδή, είδη που αποτελούν δείκτες Βιοποικιλότητας, κ.α. Για το σκοπό αυτό διεξάγονται καταμετρήσεις σε 55 αντιπροσωπευτικές διαδρομές παγκυπρίως συνολικού μήκους 488.8 χλμ. τρεις φορές το χρόνο, (χειμερινή περίοδος Ιανουάριος – Φεβρουάριος) και θερινή (Ιούνιος – Ιούλιος) όπου γίνεται εκτίμηση της αναπαραγωγής και πληθυσμιακής κατάστασης των ειδών. Επίσης κατά το καλοκαίρι διεξάγεται και μία νυκτερινή παγκύπρια καταμέτρηση. Επιπρόσθετα διεξάγονται μηνιαίες καταμετρήσεις υδροβίων πτηνών που διαχειμάζουν στους Κυπριακούς υδροβιότοπους με μεγαλύτερη βαρύτητα στις αλυκές Ακρωτηρίου και Λάρνακας. Παρόμοιες καταμετρήσεις διεξάγονται και σε περιοχές χαρακτηρισμένες ως Ζώνες Ειδικής Προστασίας (Ζ.Ε.Π). Προκλήσεις και προγραμματισμός για μελλοντικές δράσεις και έρευνα αφορούν τη διατήρηση των περιοχών ΖΕΠ ή άλλων σημαντικών περιοχών για τη πτηνοπανίδα από μη συμβατές δραστηριότητες ή έργα τα οποία μειώνουν ή υποβαθμίζουν τις περιοχές αυτές, ειδικότερα εντός ιδιωτικών εκτάσεων, αφού ένα σημαντικό μέρος των περιοχών ΖΕΠ αφορούν ιδιωτική γη. Η κατανόηση και η αποδοχή των περιοχών ΖΕΠ από τις τοπικές κοινωνίες είναι επίσης μία σημαντική παράμετρος. Μία άλλη σημαντική πρόκληση αφορά το πρόβλημα της παράνομης παγίδευσης αγρίων πτηνών με τη χρήση δικτύων, ξοβέργων και ηχοπαραγωγικών συσκευών. Παρόλο που έχει επιτευχθεί σημαντική πρόοδος σε σχέση με πριν μία δεκαετία, οι αριθμοί παγίδευσης εξακολουθούν να παραμένουν σε μη αποδεκτά επίπεδα. Η Υπηρεσία Θήρας & Πανίδας κάθε χρόνο την τελευταία πενταετία καταγγέλλει περί τις 300 – 350 υποθέσεις λαθροθηρίας και εγκλημάτων κατά της άγριας ζωής, ενώ οι μισές περίπου από αυτές αφορούν υποθέσεις παράνομης παγίδευσης.
achievements_trans: The Republic of Cyprus has transposed the EU Birds Directive (2009/147/EC) into Cyprus law and this is implemented by the  Ministry of Interior (Game & Fauna Service). The Directive and equivalent Cyprus law require, among other things, the designation of the most important areas for the conservation of Birds Directive Annex I species, migrants and wintering water-birds as Special Protection Areas (SPA), which are included in the Natura 2000 Network. Currently, in the Republic of Cyprus, 30 areas have been designated as SPAs (7 in 2005, 12 in 2007, 7 in 2008, 3 in 2009 and 2 in 2013 [also 1 in 2013 which is an extension of an already existing area], covering about 16.5 % of the Republic of Cyprus total land area. This is an important part of the natural reserve of the Republic of Cyprus. Regarding management of the SPAs, already a contract has been signed with external consultants for the preparation of Management Plans for all SPAs. This contract also includes an extensive stakeholder consultation program. It is estimated that the SPAs Management Plans will be ready by the end of 2016, when the identified actions and measures will start to be implemented in order to achieve the goals.Regardless of the preparation of Management Plans, the protection of the SPA areas and endangered species is achieved through specific actions, measures and programs implemented by the Game & Fauna Service, along with other partners. Below, some indicative examples are briefly described.1.	Project for the reinforcement of the Cypriot population of Griffon Vultures (Gyps Fulvus) with individuals from CreteThe Project 'GYPAS' aims at enriching the extremely small population of the Griffon Vulture in Cyprus with individuals from Crete, so that the population can recover. The ‘Gypas’ Project started in September 2011 and ends on January 2014. The programme is led by the Game & Fauna Service  in Cyprus, and partners in the program are BirdLife Cyprus and the Department of Forestry in Cyprus, and the Natural History Museum of Crete and Gortyna Municipality in Crete. The actions that have taken place as part of the project include building a new holding cage at Limnatis, extending an existing cage in Agios Giannis in Pafos, and building two new feeding stations for Vultures. Furthermore, other activities include: monitoring of the population, several public awareness-raising activities and the production of informational material.  In Crete, a Vulture rehabilitation centre was created for their re-introduction to the wild, monitoring of the population and public awareness-raising activities were performed. Lastly, an international conference took place in Cyprus (March 2013), with the participation of European experts. During the programme, around 30 vultures were sent from Crete to Cyprus.2.	Restoration and Management of Oroklini LakeThe 3-year LIFE project's beneficiaries are the Game & Fauna Service as lead beneficiary, BirdLife Cyprus as coordinator, the Environment Department, the Department of Forests and the Voroklini Community Council. The project started on January 2012. The LIFE Oroklini project consists of both conservation and awareness-raising actions that tackle the pressures threatening this important wetland SPA. Conservation actions include fencing of the lake to prevent disturbance from motor vehicles that enter the lake during dry seasons, removal of invasive alien plant species, planting of native shrubs and trees, water management and restoration of the area where a flea market used to operate, illegally. Many actions proposed in the Management Plan of Oroklini Lake will be implemented. The benefits from this project are many. An important wetland will be restored and this project can be the model for future projects; the project will help to raise public awareness in the area, and also the lake could be used for environmental education. At the same time, the project will help in managing the water level of the lake. Moreover, the involvement of these five beneficiaries, provided by the project, will play a great role in the project's success in restoring and managing Oroklini Lake and for building support in the community for this important site. In addition, the Game & Fauna Service implements systematic surveys and population data monitoring for various bird species. Species monitored include birds of prey, endemic birds, species with reduced and/or endangered populations at European level, corvids, species that are indicators of Biodiversity, etc. For this purpose, counts are conducted in 55 representative routes across the island of a total length of 488.8 km three times a year (winter period from January to February and summer period June-July), where an estimation of the reproduction and population status of the species is made. Also during the summer, one night monitoring campaign is conducted nationwide. Additionally, monthly counts of waterbirds wintering in Cypriot wetlands are made focussing in Larnaca and Akrotiri salt marshes. Similar counts are conducted in Special Protection Areas (SPA). The challenges and planning for future actions and research are related to SPA or other important areas for bird populations and protection of these from incompatible activities or projects that fragment or degrade these areas, especially within private land, since a significant part of the SPAs is private land. The promotion of the understanding and acceptance of SPAs by local communities is also an important priority. Another important challenge is the problem of illegal trapping of wild birds with the use of nets, limesticks and sound producing devices. Although progress has been made in comparison to 10 years ago, still the trapping numbers remain at unacceptable levels. In its capacity as guardian of the law, the Game & Fauna Service each year (during the last five years_ opens about 300-350 poaching and other wildlife violation cases. Approximately half of these cases relate to illegal trapping.
information_on_network: http://www.moi.gov.cy/MOI/Wildlife/wildlife_new.nsf/index_gr/index_gr?opendocument http://www.moi.gov.cy/MOI/Wildlife/wildlife_new.nsf/web35_gr/web35_gr?OpenDocument Please note that in the case of Cyprus, the EU Birds Directive (2009/147/EC) and indeed the EU aquis in general currently applies only in the area of the island under the effective control of the Government of the Republic of Cyprus. It does not apply in the occupied areas or in the British Sovereign Base (SBA) areas in Cyprus. This situation has presented particular challenges relating to the current reporting under article 12 of the Birds Directive, and these have been handled in the following manner: 1. Reporting on bird populations and trends under article 12 (sections 2 and 3 of the ‘Birds reports’ part of the reporting tool) has been done for the entire island (including the occupied areas and SBAs), even though data quality for the occupied areas is poorer than that for the areas under the effective control of the Government of the Republic of Cyprus and the British Sovereign Bases. 2. Reporting for populations within SPAs (section 8.1 of the ‘Birds reports’ part of the reporting tool), has been done only for the areas under the effective control of the Government of the Republic of Cyprus and the British Sovereign Bases. The SBA areas are included here because they have designated parts of one area (Akrotiri peninsula) as the equivalent of an SPA. 3. Reporting for distribution and range maps (sections 4 and 5 of the ‘Birds reports’ part of the reporting tool) is for the most part done only for the areas under the effective control of the Government of the Republic of Cyprus and the British Sovereign Bases. However, in the case of some species the distributions and ranges are for the entire island. This complete coverage was possible for species where better quality data was available for the occupied areas, including many wetland species. Complete coverage was also possible for species whose known range is restricted to the Troodos Mountains, as this area is entirely under the effective control of the Government of the Republic of Cyprus. 4. For clarity, relevant notes explaining the geographical coverage of population estimates, distributions and ranges were made under the ‘additional information’ sections under each species entry in the ‘Birds reports’ part of the reporting tool.

achievements: 1. FLEMISH REGION 1.1. Beleidsprocessen Bepaling van de instandhoudingsdoelstellingen (IHD) Voor elk habitat en soort van Europees belang werden de doelstellingen op Vlaams niveau bepaald in de gewestelijke instandhoudingsdoelstellingen (G-IHD). De G-IHD geven aan vanaf wanneer die soort of dat habitat in Vlaanderen in een gunstige staat van instandhouding verkeert en welke gebieden hiervoor essentieel zijn. Dit wil zeggen wanneer voor een soort het areaal, de populatiegrootte en de kwaliteit van het leefgebied of voor een habitat het areaal, de totale oppervlakte en de kwaliteit voldoende groot of goed zijn om duurzaam te kunnen overleven. De G-IHD werden door de Vlaamse Regering op 23 juli 2010 goedgekeurd. In afstemming met de G-IHD werden de gebiedsspecifieke doelen (S-IHD) uitgewerkt, wetenschappelijk gescreend en met doelgroepen en actoren overlegd. Op basis hiervan werden de prioritaire maatregelen per gebied aangegeven in de ontwerpen van de aanwijzingsbesluiten. Eind 2012 waren de S-IHD voor alle 38 SCI en overlappende SPA na 1ste principiële goedkeuring door de Vlaamse regering voorgelegd aan de formele adviesraden. Voor de overige SPA zijn de S-IHD in opmaak. Er werd een uitgebreid maatschappelijk overleg en participatieproces opgezet met alle relevante actoren, zowel de socio-economische groepen die actief zijn in het buitengebied in de IHD-overleggroep (landbouw, natuurbeheer, jacht, landeigenaars, economie en bosbeheerders) als de betrokken overheden in de IHD-projectgroep. Om de socio-economische actoren in staat te stellen het overleg op een professionele manier te voeren, werden ook middelen voorzien voor capaciteitsopbouw binnen elke participerende organisatie. Het kader voor het overleg in de IHD-overleggroep werd vastgelegd in een intentieverklaring die in 2009 ondertekend werd door alle betrokken organisaties. Bescherming van soorten Voor soortenbescherming en soortenbeheer werd op 15 mei 2009 een nieuw ‘soortenbesluit’ goedgekeurd dat onder meer horizontale maatregelen aangeeft voor het beheer en de bescherming van soorten met specifieke aandacht voor soorten van Europees belang. Voor de opmaak van soortenbeschermingsprogramma’s werd een format, procedure en prioritering van soorten voorbereid. Draagvlak voor natuur Op 3 juli 2009 werd het ‘Soortenschadebesluit’ goedgekeurd. Het besluit regelt de procedure en de voorwaarden voor het verkrijgen van een vergoeding voor schade veroorzaakt door beschermde soorten. Handhaving Gedurende de periode 2008-2012 werden door Natuurinspectie gerichte handhavingsacties uitgevoerd m.b.t. vangen, houden of doden van inheemse vogels. 1.2. Uitvoering De implementatie van de IHD vormt één van de drie strategische projecten van het Agentschap voor Natuur en Bos (ANB). Het bestaand instrumentarium werd geëvalueerd door de Minaraad (Adviesraad van doelgroepen) en waar nodig worden voorstellen van aanpassing voorbereid voor een effectiever en efficiëntere implementatie. In de verschillende processen van het ANB beleid wordt prioritaire aandacht gegeven aan de IHD en Natura 2000: Natuur- en bosgebieden Het beheer van natuur- en bosgebieden in Natura 2000 wordt verder afgestemd op de realisatie van de instandhoudingsdoelen. De oppervlakte Natura 2000 met een goedgekeurd beheerplan (SCI en SPA) kwam eind 2012 op 40.916 ha, een 25% van de totale oppervlakte Natura 2000. Alle bestaande beheerplannen worden gescreend en waar nodig wordt de focus op instandhoudingsdoelen verscherpt. Daarnaast is een nieuwe benadering uitgewerkt voor multifunctioneel beheer met een geïntegreerd beheerplan voor ruimere gebieden met de diverse landeigenaars of beheerders en een takenverdeling voor de realisatie van de doelstellingen en een passend stimulerend beleid. Voor de concrete begeleiding van maatregelen op terrein werd in samenwerking met het INBO een vademecum inzake beheermaatregelen opgesteld. Bij de aankopen van terreinen wordt prioriteit gegeven aan gebieden met kwetsbare natuurwaarden en gebieden gelegen in Natura 2000. In de periode 2008-2012 werd in totaal 5.749 ha aangekocht waardoor de totale oppervlakte van de terreinen in eigendom van ANB kwam op 37.335 ha waarvan 63% in Natura 2000 gelegen is. Soortenbescherming Voor de screening van projecten/plannen met mogelijke impact op Natura 2000 werd een globale aanpak uitgewerkt om ‘de passende beoordeling’ meer op maat en toegankelijker te kunnen maken. De opmaak van de soortenbeschermingsplannen voor de kwartelkoning en grauwe kiekendief werd opgestart in uitvoering van de instandhoudingsdoelstellingen voor deze soorten. Er werd gericht gewerkt aan het bestrijden van invasieve exoten (Nijlgans, rosse stekelstraat). Natuurinrichtingsprojecten Via Natuurinrichtingsprojecten worden natuurwaarden hersteld en uitgebreid en infrastructuur voor toegankelijkheid aangelegd. Van de 24 projecten die opgestart werden in de rapporteringsperiode ligt een 50% van de totale oppervlakte van de projectgebieden (ca. 9400 ha) in Natura 2000. Het grootste deel van deze oppervlakte is ook Vogelrichtlijngebied. Samenwerking Voor de realisatie van Natura 2000 is de opzet van samenwerking met andere overheden en doelgroepen cruciaal. In het kader van het IHD-proces werd de opmaak van engagementen met de diverse actoren opgestart. Bestaande samenwerkingsprogramma’s leveren hiervoor het voorbeeld van goed praktijk, zoals: Met het Ministerie van Defensie: met het beheer van Natura 2000 op militaire domeinen worden de investering van het project Danah op langetermijn verder gezet: http://www.DANAH.be. Met het Havenbedrijf Antwerpen en Natuurpunt werd in 2011 de uitwerking van een gebiedsgericht soortenbeschermingsprogramma voor het Antwerpse havengebied opgestart: http://www.portofantwerp.com/nl/natuur. Life-projecten onder thema Natuur worden aangevraagd voor de realisatie van duurzaam herstel van habitats en soorten van Europees belang en landschappelijke verbetering en openstelling van Natura 2000-gebieden. Tijdens de rapporteringsperiode werden 10 nieuwe LIFE-projecten voor acties in Natura 2000 in Vlaanderen goedgekeurd. http://www.natuurenbos.be/nl-BE/Over-ons/Projecten.aspx http://www.natuurenbos.be/nl-BE/Natuurbeleid/Natuur/Natura_2000/Geen_verre_toekomstmuziek/Life_en_Interreg.aspx http://www.natuurpunt.be/nl/natuurbehoud/natura-_273.aspx Er werden samenwerkingsverbanden opgesteld tussen natuurbeheerders en waterbeheerders voor rivierherstel in SPA Demervallei. Onderzoek Bij het wetenschappelijk onderzoek werd prioritair aandacht gegeven aan de kennisopbouw over habitats en soorten van Europees belang en de IHD: wetenschappelijke basis voor de bepaling en evaluatie van de G-IHD en S-IHD. Communicatie Voor de algemene communicatie over Natura 2000 en over het proces voor de opmaak van de IHD werd een online nieuwsbrief ontwikkeld. De voorbereiding van een overkoepelende website Natura 2000 werd in samenwerking met het INBO opgestart. 2. BRUSSELS REGION Daar er slechts zeer weinig soorten van Bijlage I van de vogelrichtlijn in het Brussels Hoofdstedelijk Gewest aanwezig zijn en deze in erg geringe aantallen voorkomen, zijn er geen speciale beschermingszones (SPA/ZPS) ingesteld voor vogels. In het Brussels Hoofdstedelijk Gewest werden echter wel habitatrichtlijngebieden afgebakend. Juridische maatregelen werden genomen op het vlak van: - De Ordonnantie betreffende het Natuurbehoud (1/3/2012). Alle Europese vogelsoorten genieten een strikte bescherming. Acht vogelsoorten van communautair en drie van regionaal beland komen voor. - Opmaak van aanwijzingsbesluiten voor drie SBZ’s waarin instandhoudingsdoelstellingen worden beschreven voor soorten van communautair en gewestelijk belang. - Voorbereiding tot de bestrijding van invasieve soorten. Concrete maatregelen op het terrein werden genomen: - Aanvullende, artificiële kunstnesten (broedwand voor Ijsvogel, nestbakken voor Slechtvalk) - Opmaak van beheerplannen, met aandacht voor het behoud van dood hout en de bevordering van het natuurlijke rijpingsproces van bossen - Gerichte handhavingsacties door inspectiediensten m.b.t. het vangen, houden of doden van inheemse vogels + het respecteren van het voederverbod in parken en andere groene ruimten. Monitoring en rapportering: De algemene toestand van de avifauna in het Brussels Hoofdstedelijk Gewest wordt op vraag van Leefmilieu Brussel opgevolgd door de vzw AVES, die hiervoor een gewestelijk toelage krijgt. Dit onderzoek kadert in het algemene “Informatie- en Toezichtsnetwerk van het leefmilieu aan de hand van bio-indicatoren”. Zowel langlopende monitoringprojecten als eenmalige inventarisaties komen aan bod. Hieronder worden de belangrijkste pijlers van dit onderzoek kort besproken: - Sinds 1992 worden trends van algemene broedvogels gemonitord d.m.v. de methode van de luisterpunten. - Jaarlijks enkele bijzondere broedvogels opgevolgd. Het gaat om koloniebroeders zoals de Huiszwaluw, verwilderde watervogels en Invasieve exoten. Bij deze laatste behoort de monitoring van de slaapplaatsen van Halsbandparkieten. - Jaarlijks wordt een gebiedsdekkende watervogeltelling georganiseerd tijdens de winter. Bijzondere aandacht gaat uit naar slaapplaatsen van Aalscholvers. De wetenschappelijke opvolging van trekvogels a.d.h.v. ringwerk wordt in België gecoördineerd door het Koninklijk Belgisch Instituut voor Natuurwetenschappen en wordt in Brussel hoofdzakelijk uitgevoerd door de ‘Commission Ornithologique de Watermael-Boitsfort’. Deze natuurvereniging heeft haar ringstation op het Silexdomein in Watermaal-Bosvoorde. In 2011 werd door Leefmilieu Brussel – BIM een overheidsopdracht uitbesteed inzake de ‘opvolging van de Lokale Staat van Instandhouding van soorten in het Brussels Hoofdstedelijk Gewest’. Hierin werden acht vogelsoorten opgenomen die vermeld staan in bijlage 1 van de Vogelrichtlijn en die voorkomen in het Brussels Hoofdstedelijk Gewest. Het gaat om zes broedvogels en twee overwinteraars/doortrekkers. Losse, aanvullende waarnemingen worden verkregen via www.bru.waarnemingen.be. 3. WALLOON REGION After the transposition of the “Habitats” and “Birds” directives in Walloon regional law during the 2001-2007 period as well as selection of pSIC and the notification of the 240 Walloon SIC by European Commission, the 2007-2013 period has especially permit to continue the stabilization and the consolidation of the system. Thus the adoption of different legal texts and various administrative tools have contributed to gradually implement and adopt the SPA, the conservation measures, the conservation objectives for birds of European interest together with the management and the restoration of their habitats. The different orders of the Walloon government which were adopted since 2008 are: 23.10.2008 Arrêté du Gouvernement wallon fixant certaines modalités du régime préventif applicable aux sites Natura 2000, modifié par l&arrêté du Gouvernement wallon du 29 octobre 2012 (M.B. 12.11.2012) 15.02.2010 Arrêté ministériel établissant les modèles des formulaires visés aux articles 1er, alinéa 1er, 5, § 2, alinéa 1er et 7, § 1er, alinéa 1er, de l&arrêté du Gouvernement wallon du 23 octobre 2008 fixant certaines modalités du régime préventif applicable aux sites Natura 2000 24.03.2011 Arrêté du Gouvernement wallon portant les mesures préventives générales applicables aux sites Natura 2000 ainsi qu&aux sites candidats au réseau Natura 2000, modifié par l&arrêté du Gouvernement wallon du 29 octobre 2012 (M.B. 12.11.2012) 19.05.2011 Arrêté du Gouvernement wallon fixant les types d&unités de gestion susceptibles d&être délimitées au sein d&un site Natura 2000 ainsi que les interdictions et mesures préventives particulières qui y sont applicables 08.11.2012 Arrêté du Gouvernement wallon relatif aux indemnités et subventions octroyées dans les sites Natura 2000 ainsi que dans les sites candidats au réseau Natura 2000 et dans la structure écologique principale 28.03.2013 Arrêté du Gouvernement wallon arrêtant le règlement d&ordre intérieur des Commissions de conservation des sites Natura 2000 The height first designation orders for eigth Natura 2000 sites were adopted by the Walloon Government. The designation orders for the other sites were wrote and submitted for a public consultation. They should soon be adopted. The agreement between the public service and the association Aves-Natagora for the "Support to Implementation of the Birds Directive" which took place in 2007 allows to benefit from the achievements of the volunteer ornithologists network and from the expertise of the Research Department of Aves-Natagora to face the implementation of the Birds Directive. In particular : • To identify habitats of species and to define areas and management units. • To gather, to ensure the homogenization and to complete all available ornithological information for the Natura 2000 sites. This information will be used to prepare the detailed mapping of the sites and to establish the conservation status in order to use these to define management units and conservation measures. • To update and to finalize the "habitats books" for birds in which the criteria for establishing conservation status for each species per site will be detailed. • To generate useful cartograhic information for the conservation of some birds from annex I of the directive (Harriers, Corncrake) and to organize the transfer of information to the relevant departments of the administration. The transmission of information may in some cases be very fast and fit into an alert system for the purposes of protection of individuals and nests. Preparation of reporting under the European Birds Directive (Article 12, year 2007-2013). 4. FEDERAL Adoption of the Management Plan for the three SPAs (and also the SAC Trapegeer-Stroombank) in the Belgian part of the North Sea (25 July 2009) and implementation of the actions foreseen on the management plan. Scientific report on conservation objectives (Instandhoudingsdoelstellingen) for the marine Natura 2000 sites and preparation of a formal proposal for the establishment of conservation objectives for the 3 SPAs.

achievements: Nach der Vogelschutzrichtlinie treffen die Mitgliedstaaten Maßnahmen, um die natürlich vorkommenden Vogelarten auf den in Art. 2 näher beschriebenen Stand zu bringen. Zu den zentralen Schutzinstrumenten der Vogelschutzrichtlinie zählt die Einrichtung von Vogelschutzgebieten. So sind für die Vogelarten des Anhangs I und für die regelmäßig auftretenden Zugvogelarten (Art. 4 (2)) die zahlen- und flächenmäßig geeignetsten Gebiete zu Schutzgebieten zu erklären. Mit der Einstellung des Vertragsverletzungsverfahrens 2001/5117 im Oktober 2009 wurde die Ausweisung von Vogelschutzgebieten im Berichtszeitraum in Deutschland abgeschlossen. Im letzten Berichtszeitraum (Stand Juni 2007) gab es 658 Vogelschutzgebiete mit einem Flächenanteil von 9,4 % an der Landfläche Deutschlands. Während des jetzigen Berichtszeitraumes (2008-2012) sind weitere 82 Gebiete gemeldet worden. Der Meldestand lag am 30.10.2012 bei 740 Gebieten mit einer Gesamtfläche von 5.995.781 ha (inklusive der Watt-, Bodden-, Meeresfläche sowie der Fläche des bundesdeutschen Bodensees nach Angaben des jeweiligen Bundeslandes). Bezogen auf die Landfläche entspricht dies einem Anteil von nun 11,2 %, was einen großen Erfolg für den Natur- und Vogelschutz und einen wichtigen Beitrag zur Sicherung der biologischen Vielfalt bedeutet. Für die Vogelschutzgebiete sind die nötigen Erhaltungsmaßnahmen festzulegen und ggf. Managementpläne (vgl. Art.6, Abs. 1 der FFH-Richtlinie) aufzustellen, in denen konkrete Schutzmaßnahmen ausgearbeitet und umgesetzt werden. Die Erstellung der Managementpläne schreitet in den Bundesländern voran (siehe Anhang I Punkt 4). Momentan sind es 143 Vogelschutzgebiete in Deutschland, für die es mindestens in Teilen Managementpläne gibt. Für weitere 158 Vogelschutzgebiete sind Managementpläne in Planung. Die Erstellung von Managementplänen wird in einigen Bundesländern auch über Fördermittel aus dem Europäischen Landwirtschaftsfonds für die Entwicklung des ländlichen Raumes (ELER) finanziert. Agrarumwelt- und Vertragsnaturschutzprogramme flankieren die Umsetzung der Managementpläne. Deutschland hat ein allgemeines Schutzsystem etabliert, das Zugriff und Handel mit auf dem Gebiet der Mitgliedstaaten natürlich vorkommenden Arten verbietet, bzw. nur nach den weiteren Maßgaben der Richtlinie erlaubt. Die Bejagung in Deutschland wird im Einklang mit der Richtlinie durchgeführt. Bei einigen Vogelarten mit starken Bestandsrückgängen werden Erhaltungsanstrengungen in Deutschland durch die Jagd auf diese Arten außerhalb Deutschlands beeinträchtigt. Für bestimmte Vogelarten werden spezifische Artenhilfsprogramme durchgeführt, die sich auch an den Aktions- und Managementplänen der Europäischen Kommission, der Berner Konvention sowie des Afrikanisch-Eurasischen Wasservogelübereinkommens orientieren. Bei einem Teil der Vogelarten des Anhang I, für die bislang Artenhilfsprogramme und spezielle Schutzmaßnahmen umgesetzt wurden, zeigen sich inzwischen positive Bestandsentwicklungen. Dies betrifft insbesondere Großvogelarten wie z. B. Schwarzstorch, Kranich, Großtrappe, Fisch- und Seeadler, Wanderfalke und Wiesenweihe. Die Arten profitieren von gezielten Hilfsmaßnahmen wie z. B. der Einrichtung von Ruhezonen, dem Gelegeschutz oder Lebensraummanagement. Dies hat u.a. bei Schwarzstorch, Seeadler und Wanderfalke auch zu einer Verbesserung der Gefährdungseinstufung in der bundesdeutschen Roten Liste geführt. Allerdings ist die Bestandssituation der Vogelarten der offenen Kulturlandschaft, insbesondere der am Boden brütenden Vogelarten, trotz intensiver Schutzmaßnahmen nach wie vor ungünstig. Wiesenvögel (z.B. Uferschnepfe, Großer Brachvogel, Bekassine, Kiebitz) zählen aktuell zu den am stärksten gefährdeten Brutvogelgruppen, Feldvogelarten zeigen starke Bestandsrückgänge, weshalb sich die Zahl der Feldvögel in den letzten 30 Jahren in Deutschland halbiert hat. Als bedeutsame Faktoren sind dabei die Zerstörung des Lebensraumes u.a. durch den Rückgang an Brachflächen, der Rückgang von (extensiv bewirtschaftetem) Grünland sowie die zunehmende Nutzungsintensivierung und der zunehmende Anbau von Energiepflanzen sowie die Bejagung außerhalb Deutschlands zu nennen. Es gibt eine Reihe von positiven Beispielen, die belegen, dass durch die Kombination aus Gebietsmanagement und einer Kooperation mit den Landwirt/innen gute Erfolge erzielt werden können. Es besteht aber weiterhin dringender Handlungsbedarf, innerhalb und auch außerhalb der Schutzgebiete Erhaltungsmaßnahmen für die Arten der Agrarlandschaft zu ergreifen. Die Errichtung von on- und off-shore Windenergieanlagen stellt einen weiteren an Bedeutung zunehmenden Beeinträchtigungsfaktor für die Avifauna in Deutschland dar. Daher hat die Länderarbeitsgemeinschaft der Vogelschutzwarten im Jahr 2007 Empfehlungen für fachlich erforderliche artspezifische Mindestabstände zu Windenergieanlagen erstellt, die derzeit überarbeitet werden. Teilweise gibt es auch auf Länderebene entsprechende Ausarbeitungen. Diese bilden bei der Planung und Zulassung von Windenergieanlagen eine Richtschnur, um negative Auswirkungen auf Vogelarten zu vermeiden bzw. zu minimieren. Anfang 2008 ist die Bund-Länder-Verwaltungsvereinbarung zum Vogelmonitoring in Deutschland in Kraft getreten, mit der Bund und Länder die gemeinsame bundesweite Koordination der ehrenamtlichen Vogelmonitoringprogramme sowie die Datenaufbereitung durch den Dachverband Deutscher Avifaunisten (DDA) finanzieren. Mit dem im Berichtszeitraum umgesetzten bundesweiten Vogelmonitoring können auf nationaler Ebene weitgehende Aussagen zur Situation der Vogelwelt in Deutschland, zur Notwendigkeit und Steuerung von Schutzmaßnahmen und zum Erfolg von Managementmaßnahmen in Bezug auf den Erhaltungszustand von Arten erzielt werden. Für die Erstellung des nationalen Berichtes nach Art. 12 VSchRL konnten die Informationen aus dem Projekt Atlas deutscher Brutvogelarten (ADEBAR) umfänglich genutzt werden. Die Kartierungen für dieses Projekt erfolgten von 2005 - 2009, anschließend die Datenzusammenführung und -prüfung durch den Dachverband Deutscher Avifaunisten. Die Publikation dieses Grundlagenwerks für den Vogelschutz ist im Jahr 2013 vorgesehen. Zudem wurde für die Erstellung des Berichtes nach Art. 12 VSchRL auf die Monitoringprogramme der Bundesländer zurückgegriffen. Ein weiteres Instrument zur Umsetzung der Vogelschutzrichtlinie ist das Programm LIFE-Natur. Hier gibt es im Teilbereich Natur & Biologische Vielfalt mehrere Projekte, deren Förderung im Berichtszeitraum begonnen hat und die den Erhalt gefährdeter Vogelarten, z.B. Uferschnepfe, Wachtelkönig oder Seggenrohrsänger zum Inhalt haben. Zur Umsetzung der Nationalen Strategie zur Biologischen Vielfalt gibt es seit 2011 das Bundesförderprogramm zur Biologischen Vielfalt. Ein Förderschwerpunkt liegt auf den Arten, für die Deutschland international eine hohe Verantwortung hat. Darunter sind auch sieben Vogelarten, für die zukünftig Maßnahmen ergriffen werden sollen, um langfristig überlebensfähige Populationen dieser Arten zu gewährleisten. Durch die Vogelschutzrichtlinie besteht auch eine Verpflichtung zur Förderung von Forschung, insbesondere zur Überprüfung der Vogelbestände und hinsichtlich bestehender und möglicher Gefährdungen. Die Rote Liste zu wandernden Vogelarten wird derzeit zusammengestellt. Einen aktuellen Forschungsschwerpunkt bilden Untersuchungen zur Auswirkung des Klimawandels auf die Vogelbestände. Deutschland hat die relevanten Sanktionierungen aus der Umweltstrafrechtsrichtlinie in Bezug auf die Vogelschutzrichtlinie umgesetzt.
achievements_trans: Under the Birds Directive, Member States are to take measures to adapt the population of naturally occurring species of wild birds to the level specified in Article 2. One of the key conservation instruments under the Birds Directive is the creation of special protection areas (SPAs). The directive stipulates that the most suitable territories in number and size must be classified as SPAs for the conservation of the species listed in Annex I and for regularly occurring migratory species (Article 4 (2)). The infringement procedure 2001/5117 was discontinued in October 2009, marking the completion of the designation of SPAs in Germany during the current reporting period. In the last reporting period (as at June 2007) there were 658 SPAs covering 9.4% of Germany"s total terrestrial area. A further 82 sites were registered in the reporting period 2008 to 2012. As at 30 October 2012, according to the information from the German Laender, 740 sites were designated as SPAs, covering 5,995,781 ha (including tidal flats (Watt), shallow bays (Bodden), marine areas and the German area of Lake Constance). Protected areas thus now account for 11.2% of Germany"s total terrestrial area, representing a major success for nature and bird conservation and a key contribution to safeguarding biological diversity. The necessary conservation measures must be defined for the SPAs, including, if required, management plans (cf. Habitats Directive Article 6 (1)), which formulate and implement specific conservation measures. The German Laender are making progress in the adoption of management plans (see Annex I (4)). Management plans already exist, at least in part, for 143 German SPAs and are currently being drafted for another 158 SPAs. In some German Laender, the preparation of the management plans is also financed through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD). Implementation of the management plans is supported by agro-environmental and contract-based nature conservation programmes. Germany has established a general system of conservation, which either prohibits access to and trade with species which occur naturally on the territory of the Member States or allows this only in accordance with the provisions of the Directive. Hunting in Germany must comply with the Directive. In the case of some species of wild birds with strongly declining populations, conservation efforts in Germany are being hampered by the hunting of these species in other countries. Concrete species conservation programmes are in place for certain bird species. These programmes also draw on European Commission action and management plans, the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats and the Agreement on the Conservation of African-Eurasian Migratory Waterbirds. Positive population trends have been recorded recently in the case of some Annex I birds for which species conservation programmes and special conservation measures have been implemented. This is particularly the case for large birds such as black stork, crane, great bustard, osprey, white-tailed eagle, peregrine falcon and montagu"s harrier. The species benefit from targeted measures, for instance the establishment of no-admittance areas, clutch protection and habitat management. For black stork, white-tailed eagle, peregrine falcon and other species these measures have improved their status on Germany"s Red List of endangered species. Nevertheless, the population status of bird species of open landscapes, especially ground-nesting birds, remains poor despite intensive conservation measures. Meadow birds (e.g. black-tailed godwit, curlew, snipe, lapwing) are currently among the most endangered groups of breeding birds, field bird species show a heavy decline in populations, with their numbers halving over the past 30 years. Significant contributing factors are the loss of habitats, for instance due to the decrease in fallow areas and (extensively used) grassland, an increased intensification of agriculture, the rise in the cultivation of energy crops, and hunting in other countries. A number of examples demonstrate that the combination of site management and cooperation with farmers can lead to positive results. However, there is still an urgent need to implement conservation measures for farmland species, both within and outside the SPAs. Construction of onshore and offshore wind turbines is another increasingly relevant source of disturbance for birds in Germany. For this reason, in 2007 the German Inter-State Working Group of Bird Conservation Observatories (LAG-VSW) recommended species-specific minimum distances for wind turbines. These recommendations are currently being revised. For some species, there are also corresponding recommendations at German Länder level. The recommendations act as a guideline in the planning and authorisation of wind turbines to avoid or minimise negative impacts on bird species. An administrative agreement between the German Federation and the German Laender on bird monitoring entered into force at the beginning of 2008. Under this agreement, the Federation and the Laender fund the joint national coordination of voluntary bird monitoring programmes, as well as the data analysis by the umbrella association Dachverband Deutscher Avifaunisten (Federation of German Avifaunists, DDA). Nationwide bird monitoring during the reporting period allows comprehensive statements to be made on the status of birdlife in Germany, the need for and evaluation of conservation measures and on the degree of success of management in improving the conservation status of species. Information collected through the ADEBAR project (Atlas of German breeding bird species) was used extensively in the compilation of the national report pursuant to Article 12 of the Birds Directive. Mapping for this project was carried out between 2005 and 2009; the data was subsequently consolidated and reviewed by the DDA. The atlas as a fundamental work on bird conservation is scheduled for publication in 2013. The compilation of the report under Article 12 of the Birds Directive also draws on the monitoring programmes of the German Laender. Another instrument for implementing the Birds Directive is the LIFE-Nature programme. During the reporting period, a number of projects dealing with the conservation of endangered bird species, e.g. black-tailed godwit, corncrake and aquatic warbler, were funded as part of the Nature, Biodiversity subject area. The Federal Biological Diversity Programme was established in 2011 to promote the implementation of the National Strategy on Biological Diversity. A particular focus of funding is on species for which Germany has a high international responsibility, including seven bird species for which measures will be taken in future to ensure viable populations in the long term. The Birds Directive also stipulates that Member States must support research, in particular with regard to monitoring bird populations and ascertaining existing and potential threats. The Red List for migratory bird species is currently being compiled. A current focus of research is the study of climate change impacts on bird populations. Germany has implemented the relevant penalties under the Directive on the protection of the environment through criminal law with regard to the Birds Directive.

protection_of_species: Informationen zum Schutz der Seetaucher in der deutschen AWZ der Nord- und Ostsee sind auf Anfrage beim BMU erhältlich. Informationen zum Artenschutz im Saarland sind auf Anfrage bei der für den Artenschutz zuständigen Stelle beim Landesamt für Umwelt- und Arbeitsschutz, Zentrum für Biodokumentation, Am Bergwerk Reden 11, D-66578 Schiffweiler, info.biodoku@lua.saarland.de, bzw. +49 681 501 3452 erhältlich. Anmerkung zur Gefährdungsangabe "Forstliches Flächenmanagement": Soweit diese Listung Maßnahmen aus der Rubrik "Forst" enthält, ist dies als Hinweis auf potenzielle Risiken zu verstehen. Die Liste ist keine Beschreibung einer konkreten, auf Bundesebene real bestehenden Gefahr für den Bestand der jeweiligen Vogelart. Für die Landesforstverwaltungen wurden in den meisten Bundesländern verbindliche Grundsätze für die Bewirtschaftung des Waldes festgelegt, die naturschutzfachliche Aspekte wie z.B. den Biotopverbund sowie den Natura-2000-Artenschutz beinhalten. Die in Deutschland geltenden wald- und naturschutzrechtlichen Bestimmungen sowie Sanktionsmöglichkeiten bei Verstößen sollen gewährleisten, dass diese Gefährdungen auf Bundesebene keine relevante Bedeutung erlangen. Bei einer ganzen Reihe von geschützten Zugvogelarten wird der Erhaltungszustand in Deutschland maßgeblich dadurch beeinträchtigt, dass den Beständen dieser Arten außerhalb Deutschlands in erheblichem Maße nachgestellt wird. Weitere Forschungen und Arbeiten: Der Einfluss extensiver Jagd auf den Wasservogelbestand an einem Rastplatz der Schnatterente (Anas strepera) in Süddeutschland, Peter Linderoth, Wildforschungsstelle, Aulendorf 2007, Band 6. Bestandsentwicklung der Tundra- und Wald-Saatgans im Westen Europas 1958/59 - 2006/07 nach Timmerman et al. 1976, Wetlands International goose database, eigene Daten BMEL. achievements: Sverige har under perioden designerat 15 nya SPA-områden á totalt 118 266 ha. Sverige gjorde 2010 en utvärdering av det befintliga nätverket för skydd av fåglar (SPA). Rapporten innehåller översyn och analys av nätverket på nationell nivå, samt jämförelse med övriga medlemsländers nätverk. Rapporten redovisar även förslag på hur Sverige ska gå till väga för att nå Kommissionen mål om att nätverket ska vara "till stor del fullständigt" Naturvårdsverket gjorde 2012 på uppdrag av regeringen en översyn av övervakningen av sjöfåglar, med särskild fokus på de arter som de senaste åren visat kraftig vikande trender. I rapporten föreslås omfattande program som syftar till att täcka upp för brister i dagens övervakning. Programmen är riktade mot nationsöverspännande ansatser, då många av de berörda arterna tillbringar sina olika livsfaser i ett flertal länder. I linje med ovanstående har den allmänna jakttiden för svärta tagits bort. Forskning relaterat till övervakning och bevarande av fåglar stöds aktivt och löpande. Tex könskvoter hos alfågel, vilket avsevärt förbättrar kunskapen om en art med kraftigt sviktande trend. Ett antal Life-projekt som på olika sätt gynnar fåglar har startats upp och löpt under rapporteringsperioden, bla åtgärdsarbete med viktiga habitat för våtmarksfåglar i Asköviken. Under perioden har nio åtgärdsprogram för hotade arter tagits fram eller reviderats, och ytterligare fyra är under framtagande. Naturvårdsverket har tagit fram en handbok för tolkning av fridlysningsbestämmelser, vilket har haft en positiv effekt på kunskapen om Artikel 5 i Fågeldirektivet. Sverige har under rapporteringsperioden även designerat 15 nya Ramsar-områden, som även om det inte ligger under Fågeldirektivet likväl har haft en gynnande effekt på ett flertal fågelarter.
achievements_trans: During the reporting period 15 new SPA areas have been designated in Sweden, covering in total 118 266 ha. In 2010, an overview of the SPA network in Sweden was carried out. The report contains an analysis on a national level, as well as a comparison with other Member States network. In the overview, actions that will help reaching the goal of the Commission that the network should be largely complete are listed. In 2012 the Swedish EPA reviewed the monitoring programs covering seabirds, with special emphasis on those species that have seen dramatic declines in the recent years. New monitoring programmes were proposed to cover gaps that were identified in the current programmes. The programmes also focus on joint actions, as several of the species covered spend different parts of their life cycle in more than one country. In addition to the above mentioned programmes, the general hunting season on Velvet scoter has been excluded. Research related to monitoring and management of birds is actively supported. F.e. research on sex ratio in Long-tailed duck, which will be substantially imorve the knowledge about a dramatically declining species. A number of Life projects have been initiated during the reporting period, or are currently running. F.e. management actions being carried out in the area of Asköviken, which improves the habitats for wetland birds. Nine Single Species Action Plans have been developed during the reporting period, as well as four plans being under development. Thw Swedish EPA has produced guidelines on have to interpret regulations regarding the protection of species, which in turn is beneficial to the knowledge about the implementation of the Article 5 in the Birds Directive. During the reporting period, Sweden has designatedd 15 new Ramsar sites. Although not connected to the requirements under The Birds Directive, it is still beneficial to a large amount of wetland bird species.
